elements.content: The multitopic ligand O,O′-bisnicotinic acid tetraethylene glycol, L, was designed for the coordination of two distinct types of metal ions. In this work, we describe how the O-donor part of L is used to coordinate to alkaline earth metal ions and that the N-donor atoms of L bind to group 11 elements. This makes L a suitable ligand for the combination of both metal ion types within the same compound. This concept will be exemplified by highlighting the pure Ca2+ complexes, a Cu+-coordination polymer network, as well as the mixed-metal compound, which can be used as a single-source precursor for mixed-metal oxide materials.

elements.content:
A multitopic ligand is used to selectively assemble different metal ions, generating single-source precursors for oxide materials.

Introduction

In previous works, complexes of alkaline earth metal ions were used as precursors for the synthesis of mixed-metal oxides, for example, high-Tc superconductors, focusing on the volatility of the products and their capacity of forming the target oxides. Such metal oxides find applications in many areas, such as magnetism, superconductivity, optics, and electronics. The composition of such materials can be relatively simple, as in the ferroelectric BaTiO3, or more complicated, as in the superconductors YBa2Cu3O7−δ (YBCO) or Bi2Sr2Ca n Cu n+1O2n+6 (BSCCO). Their synthesis may occur either by solid-state reactions requiring high temperatures or by milder methods such as metal organic chemical vapor deposition ((MO-)CVD) or sol−gel techniques. For (MO-)CVD, volatile compounds of the constituting metal ions are required, which are thermally stable enough for stochiometric deposition as (thin) films on the substrate. Generally, a mixture of volatile metal compounds is used to generate the target oxide. Yet, for alkaline earth metal diketonates or ketoimines, oligomerization as well as insufficient volatility and stability are often a problem. It was therefore interesting to combine all of the required metal atoms within one single precursor, and many efforts have been made to tailor such “single-source precursors”. Yet, for example, for YBa2Cu3O7−δ (or even more complicated systems), no solution in the form of single-source precursors containing all three (or more) metal ions within one molecule has been found so far. Much effort has been put into the synthesis of mixed-metal alkoxides, which are revealed to be excellent precursors for MO-CVD or CVD. Recent results showed that it is often possible to combine as many as two different required metal ions in volatile metal organic compounds. For instance, the compounds [YBa3(OtBu)6(thd)3] and [BaCu(OtBu)2(thd)2] n (Hthd = 2,2,6,6,-tetramethyl-3,5-heptanedione) were isolated, but they possess high sublimation temperatures, even when transformed into the THF adducts, and show a tendency to decompose. There have also been several approaches to synthesize heterometallic copper(II)−alkaline-earth metal complexes, for example, calcium−copper complexes with 1,3-bis-(dimethylamino)-2-propanolato (bdmap) and trifluoroacetato ligands. In these compounds, however, the coordination of the ligand(s) to the metal ion is uncontrolled and not selective, so that the final compound cannot be predicted. To our knowledge, no conceptual approach has been made to use tailored ligands adapted to the specific properties of the metal ions. Therefore, the design of mixed-metal species is of considerable interest in relation to their potential application as precursors for (MO-)CVD or sol−gel techniques.

elements.content: We propose to design single-source precursors based on functionalized polyether molecules, since these molecules are usually stable, adaptable and flexible, and easy to handle. Thus, we developed the ligands L and L′, which allow coordination to different metal ion types via different ligating atoms (Scheme ). In the first part of this paper, the coordination behavior of L is studied. With alkaline earth metal ions such as calcium, the ligand L is supposed to wrap around the metal ion, yielding a complex in which the nitrogen atoms are expected to be oriented so as to accommodate another metal ion, for example, a transition metal ion. In the second part, we study the coordination of L to the transition metal ion alone, before combining both metal ions within one single compound in a last step. With ligand L′, we will then show that this concept works as well, presenting another heterometallic species obtained as well via the selective binding of L′ to two different metal ions.

With ligand L', we will then show that this concept works as well, presenting another heterometallic species obtained as well via the selective binding of L' to two different metal ions.

elements.content: Thus, we here report the design and synthesis of a novel ligand, its homometallic compounds obtained with calcium and copper ions, and finally a new mixed-metal calcium−copper precursor for mixed-metal oxides. We confirm the principle of selective binding of different metal ions with a second ligand. We will also show that the concept of this precursor works by presenting first decomposition experiments of the heterometallic compounds, which show that mixed-metal oxides can be obtained.
elements.clean_text: Thus, we here report the design and synthesis of a novel ligand, its homometallic compounds obtained with calcium and copper ions, and finally a new mixed-metal calcium-copper precursor for mixed-metal oxides. We confirm the principle of selective binding of different metal ions with a second ligand. We will also show that the concept of this precursor works by presenting first decomposition experiments of the heterometallic compounds, which show that mixed-metal oxides can be obtained.

elements.content: We chose the ligand O,O′-bisnicotinic acid tetraethylene glycol (L) for its potential to coordinate to two different metal ions for the generation of bimetallic species (Scheme ). In our group, ligands of the type polyethylene glycol with two nicotinic acid or isonicotinic acid functions in terminal positions are well-studied. Due to its quite long polyether chain, L can adopt different conformations. We therefore wanted to learn about the most stable one in the solid state.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Design, Synthesis, and Crystal Structure of the Ligand L [C20H24O7N2]

We chose the ligand O,O'-bisnicotinic acid tetraethylene glycol (L) for its potential to coordinate to two different metal ions for the generation of bimetallic species (Scheme ). In our group, ligands of the type polyethylene glycol with two nicotinic acid or isonicotinic acid functions in terminal positions are well-studied. Due to its quite long polyether chain, L can adopt different conformations. We therefore wanted to learn about the most stable one in the solid state.

elements.content: The synthesis of L (Scheme and Figure ) consists of a simple reaction between nicotinic acid chloride and tetraethylene glycol, heated together in a ratio of 2:1. Needlelike crystals grow from the crude product in a solution of dichloromethane/hexane after a few days. L crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Fdd2. The unit cell contains half a molecule, which is completed by symmetry through O4 (Figure a). L displays a “W”-shape conformation, with the ether groups at the ethylene units presenting a gauche conformation. Within a molecule of L, the two pyridine rings lie in mean planes, which form an angle of 76.1(1)° to each other. From C3 to its symmetry equivalent C3′, the molecule L has a length of ca. 17.7 Å (without H atoms).

From C3 to its symmetry equivalent C3', the molecule L has a length of ca. 17.7 Å (without H atoms).

elements.content: (a) Single molecule of L and numbering. (b) Fishbone arrangement along the z axis of L (hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity).
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Single molecule of L and numbering. (b) Fishbone arrangement along the z axis of L (hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity).

elements.content: The molecules of L pack in a fishbone arrangement along the z plane, with H-bonding between C10···N1, C8···O1, and C3···O2 and corresponding symmetry equivalents of neighboring molecules. Such layers are stacked on top of each other with a shortest distance of 3.58(1) Å (distance measured between both mean pyridine planes), allowing thus π interactions between the pyridine rings.
elements.clean_text: The molecules of L pack in a fishbone arrangement along the z plane, with H-bonding between C10⋅⋅⋅N1, C8⋅⋅⋅O1, and C3⋅⋅⋅O2 and corresponding symmetry equivalents of neighboring molecules. Such layers are stacked on top of each other with a shortest distance of 3.58(1) Å (distance measured between both mean pyridine planes), allowing thus π interactions between the pyridine rings.

elements.content: Under the same reaction conditions, but at a molecular ratio of 1:1 nicotinic acid chloride to tetraethylene glycol, the reaction takes place on only one side of the glycol, yielding the asymmetric ligand L′ (Scheme ). This ligand presents itself as oil and was therefore characterized via NMR. The idea of synthesizing L′ is to have less steric hindrance in order to be able to complex larger metal ions such as barium.
elements.clean_text: Under the same reaction conditions, but at a molecular ratio of 1:1 nicotinic acid chloride to tetraethylene glycol, the reaction takes place on only one side of the glycol, yielding the asymmetric ligand L' (Scheme ). This ligand presents itself as oil and was therefore characterized via NMR. The idea of synthesizing L' is to have less steric hindrance in order to be able to complex larger metal ions such as barium.

elements.content: In order to learn about the flexibility of the ligand and its capacity to adapt to different metal ions, we investigated first the coordination of L to calcium ions, then to copper ions, and finally explored the possibility of formation of a mixed-metal compound.
elements.clean_text: In order to learn about the flexibility of the ligand and its capacity to adapt to different metal ions, we investigated first the coordination of L to calcium ions, then to copper ions, and finally explored the possibility of formation of a mixed-metal compound.

elements.content: From the reaction of L with CaI2, two different forms of [Ca(L)(H2O)3]I2 are obtained, one crystallizing with chloroform (2) as a cocrystallizing solvent molecule, the other without a solvent molecule (1). Instead of one being the solvated form of the other, the two structures differ significantly from each other, as described in the following.
elements.clean_text:
Coordination of L to Calcium Ions: The Compounds [Ca(L)(H2O)3]I2 (1) and [Ca(L)(H2O)3]I2⋅(CHCl3)2 (2) Containing Isomeric Complex Cations

From the reaction of L with CaI2, two different forms of [Ca(L)(H2O)3]I2 are obtained, one crystallizing with chloroform (2) as a cocrystallizing solvent molecule, the other without a solvent molecule (1). Instead of one being the solvated form of the other, the two structures differ significantly from each other, as described in the following.

elements.content: When CaI2 is reacted with L in chloroform, a dark yellow solution is obtained after filtration of the residue. After slow evaporation at room temperature (RT), yellow rhombic crystals of 1 are obtained. Compound 1 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric, monoclinic space group P21/c. The unit cell consists of a complete molecule of 1, as shown in Figure . As expected in Scheme , the ligand L wraps around the calcium ion, changing its conformation compared to its “W” structure and coordinating with the four oxygen atoms O3, O4, O5, and O7 to the cation with distances between 2.35(1) and 2.49(9) Å. The coordination sphere around the cation is completed by three water molecules, O8, O9, and O10 (average Ca−O of 2.34 Å), to yield a distorted pentagonal-bipyramidal arrangement of O atoms, where O9 and O10 occupy the axial positions and O8 as well as the above-mentioned oxygen atoms of L are the equatorial ones. The anions I1 and I2 are H-bonded to the water molecules O8 and O10 and molecules O9 and O10, respectively, as well as their symmetry equivalents (average I1···H of 2.76(3) Å and I2···H of 2.85(1) Å), leading to a H-bonded, overall three-dimensional network in the solid state.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of [Ca(L)(H2O)3]I2, 1 

When CaI2 is reacted with L in chloroform, a dark yellow solution is obtained after filtration of the residue. After slow evaporation at room temperature (RT), yellow rhombic crystals of 1 are obtained. Compound 1 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric, monoclinic space group P21/c. The unit cell consists of a complete molecule of 1, as shown in Figure . As expected in Scheme , the ligand L wraps around the calcium ion, changing its conformation compared to its "W" structure and coordinating with the four oxygen atoms O3, O4, O5, and O7 to the cation with distances between 2.35(1) and 2.49(9) Å. The coordination sphere around the cation is completed by three water molecules, O8, O9, and O10 (average Ca-O of 2.34 Å), to yield a distorted pentagonal-bipyramidal arrangement of O atoms, where O9 and O10 occupy the axial positions and O8 as well as the above-mentioned oxygen atoms of L are the equatorial ones. The anions I1 and I2 are H-bonded to the water molecules O8 and O10 and molecules O9 and O10, respectively, as well as their symmetry equivalents (average I1⋅⋅⋅H of 2.76(3) Å and I2⋅⋅⋅H of 2.85(1) Å), leading to a H-bonded, overall three-dimensional network in the solid state.

elements.content: Cationic complex and numbering of 1 (hydrogen atoms and iodide atoms are omitted for clarity).
elements.clean_text: 2  Cationic complex and numbering of 1 (hydrogen atoms and iodide atoms are omitted for clarity).

elements.content: The surprising feature within this molecule of 1 is the asymmetric coordination of the carbonyl O atoms of L, one pointing inward (“in”), coordinating the calcium ion with O7, the other being oriented outward (“out”) with O1 pointing away from the cation. In the solid state, the “in” nicotinic acid moiety of one molecule packs with an “out” nicotinic acid of a neighbor molecule at a distance of 3.29 Å (measured between the pyridine planes of two neighbored molecules), indicating π−π stacking. The second ring at the molecule does not interact with any other molecule, so that a dimer is formed. As mentioned before, these dimers are then linked via H bonds between water molecules O8, O9, and O10 and iodide anions into a three-dimensional network.

In the solid state, the "in" nicotinic acid moiety of one molecule packs with an "out" nicotinic acid of a neighbor molecule at a distance of 3.29 Å (measured between the pyridine planes of two neighbored molecules), indicating π-π stacking. The second ring at the molecule does not interact with any other molecule, so that a dimer is formed. As mentioned before, these dimers are then linked via H bonds between water molecules O8, O9, and O10 and iodide anions into a three-dimensional network.

elements.content: A different isomer of the calcium complex is obtained when the crystallization is carried out at a lower temperature (−24 °C). Then, 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n, its unit cell consisting of a complete calcium complex as in 1, but with two additional chloroform molecules. Similar to 1, the calcium ion loses its two iodide anions from its direct coordination sphere. In contrast to 1, however, the ligand coordinates symmetrically to the cation using both carbonyl oxygen atoms O1 and O7 (with a Ca−O distance of 2.38(8) and 2.39(1) Å, respectively) and three polyether oxygen atoms, O3, O4, and O5 (average Ca−O distances 2.54(5) Å). Together with three water molecules, O8, O9, and O10 (average Ca−O distances 2.41(4) Å), this gives a higher coordination number of eight for the cation in 2 than that in 1 (Figure , Scheme ). The calcium ion thus has a square antiprismatic coordination sphere. A comparison of our data with calcium complexes involving simple polyethylene ligands and an identical coordination number shows that our distances are in the same range as the ones in the literature examples. The cationic complex forms dimers (Figure b) via hydrogen bonds between the water molecule O8 of one molecule and the nitrogen atoms N1 and N2 of the second. Offset π stacking between the pairs of pyridine rings of each cationic unit is observed at the short distance of 3.34 Å between C5 of one molecule and C16 of the neighbor pyridine group.

Crystal Structure of [Ca(L)(H2O)3]I2⋅(CHCl3)2 2 

A different isomer of the calcium complex is obtained when the crystallization is carried out at a lower temperature (-24 °C). Then, 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n, its unit cell consisting of a complete calcium complex as in 1, but with two additional chloroform molecules. Similar to 1, the calcium ion loses its two iodide anions from its direct coordination sphere. In contrast to 1, however, the ligand coordinates symmetrically to the cation using both carbonyl oxygen atoms O1 and O7 (with a Ca-O distance of 2.38(8) and 2.39(1) Å, respectively) and three polyether oxygen atoms, O3, O4, and O5 (average Ca-O distances 2.54(5) Å). Together with three water molecules, O8, O9, and O10 (average Ca-O distances 2.41(4) Å), this gives a higher coordination number of eight for the cation in 2 than that in 1 (Figure , Scheme ). The calcium ion thus has a square antiprismatic coordination sphere. A comparison of our data with calcium complexes involving simple polyethylene ligands and an identical coordination number shows that our distances are in the same range as the ones in the literature examples. The cationic complex forms dimers (Figure b) via hydrogen bonds between the water molecule O8 of one molecule and the nitrogen atoms N1 and N2 of the second. Offset π stacking between the pairs of pyridine rings of each cationic unit is observed at the short distance of 3.34 Å between C5 of one molecule and C16 of the neighbor pyridine group.

elements.content: The anion I1 forms hydrogen bonds to the water molecules O9 and O10 of one complex and O10 of a neighbor molecule (average I1−H of 2.95 Å). On the other hand, I2 forms four hydrogen bonds: to C4 and C19 and to the hydrogen atoms of both chloroform molecules (C21 and C22) with an average distance of 2.95 Å. This hydrogen bonding leads to a network in which the dimers form channels, and the chloroform molecules are located between these rows of channels.

elements.content: For comparison, the most important bond lengths and angles for 1 and 2 are listed in Table . A neat difference between the seven-coordinated compound 1 and the eight-coordinated 2 is reflected in the Ca−O bond lengths. It can be seen that the Ca−O bonds of 1 are on average shorter than the ones in compound 2. This can be explained by the fact that the calcium ion needs to pull more electron density from the oxygen atoms when only seven oxygen atoms surround it, than in the preferred eight-coordination. In order to estimate which complex, the one in 1 or the one in 2, is more stable, bond valence sums were calculated for the calcium cation in each case. For the eight-coordinated complex 2, a value of 2.16 is obtained, which is very close to the formal expected oxidation state of +2 of the Ca2+ ion (8% deviation from the assumed valence state). For compound 1, it is slightly higher (2.28), which shows that the Ca ion is more “intensely” coordinated. This difference of coordination and thus ligand conformation has an impact on other structural features of the two complexes. Thus, the pyridine rings within L of the asymmetric compound 1 form an angle of 40.6(6)°, while in compound 2, the pyridine units are almost coplanar (9.6(2)°). This difference can be explained by the missing coordination of the second carbonyl group in 1. In compound 2, the plane containing the calcium ion and the polyether oxygen atoms forms an angle of 78.2(3)° with the plane formed by the nicotinic acid units. The same plane, Ca−O3−O4−O5, in compound 1 forms an angle of 77.7(6)° with one of the nicotinic groups containing C6, O1, and N1, and the other nicotinic group C15−O7−N2 forming an angle of 43.7(9)°. Concerning the ligand conformations in 1 and 2, at least three rotations around bonds within L have to be performed to come to approximately the same ligand arrangement in both. As shown in Scheme , rotation number 1 would allow for the carbonyl group to turn inward, rendering its coordination to the cation possible. Then, however, rotation number 2 has to occur simultaneously in order to keep the nitrogen atom of the pyridine ring oriented inward as well. On the other side of the ligand, rotation number 3 will also lead to an inward turn of the pyridine nitrogen atom. Previous theoretical calculations on the flexibility of a similar ligand, but with a short ethylene bridge as a spacer, have shown that the different ligand conformations are energetically very close to each other and can easily be reached at room temperature. In solution, the ligand L alone should indeed be able to adopt many possible conformations. Upon coordination to calcium ions, the ligand has to adopt a general “U” shape. This conformation of L, especially the one in compound 2, seems to be a prerequisite for the coordination of a second metal ion type at the N-donor atoms of L, as shown in Scheme , as will be shown later.

When the synthesis of 1 and 2 is repeated several times, isomer 1 could be obtained more easily at RT with different crystallization techniques, while compound 2 can be only obtained at a low temperature (−24 °C). Furthermore, the crystals of 2 tend to melt rapidly at room temperature and in inert oil. This indicates that 1 seems to be the more stable compound at RT. The instability of 2 can presumably be explained by solvent loss when the crystal is taken out of the mother liquor. Even though nature tends toward symmetry (here, diminishing of the molecular dipole moment in 2 compared to 1), the stability of the first isomer can also be explained according to thermodynamic aspects. One is the formation of two seven-member rings in compound 2, compared to one in 1. This leads to a higher ring strain in compound 2. Furthermore, the entropy gained in 1 by the possible rotation around the C6−O1 bond certainly also contributes to the stability of 1 versus 2.

One is the formation of two seven-member rings in compound 2, compared to one in 1. This leads to a higher ring strain in compound 2. Furthermore, the entropy gained in 1 by the possible rotation around the C6-O1 bond certainly also contributes to the stability of 1 versus 2.

elements.content: A tool other than X-ray analysis used to differentiate both isomers in the solid state is IR spectroscopy, where the carbonyl band can be inspected; compound 1 shows two carbonyl bands at 1724 cm−1 and at 1697 cm−1, the first band for the coordinated CO and the lower band for the free carbonyl groups. Compound 2 exhibits, as expected, only one band at 1735 cm−1. In solution, however, 1 cannot be differentiated from 2, which indicates a fast on-and-off-coordination of O1 and O7 in both compounds. To evidence this, both complexes 1 and 2 were dissolved in acetonitrile and also in CDCl3 and measured in 1H NMR, where no obvious difference could be seen. NMR at variable temperatures (−30 to +30 °C) also did not show significant changes. The solutions were also then measured by FT-IR. The double band of compound 1 collapsed to an average, large band around 1720 cm−1. Also, the sharp carbonyl band of compound 2 disappeared. Even though the solid starting materials show a neat difference in IR, both solutions have nearly identical spectra, and it is no longer possible to identify both compounds.

elements.content:
Having shown that ligand L uses the oxygen donor atoms to coordinate to alkaline earth metal ions, we next tested its coordination behavior toward copper ions.

Coordination of <bold>L</bold> to Copper Ions: Crystal Structure of {[Cu<sub>4</sub>I<sub>4</sub>(<bold>L</bold>)<sub>2</sub>](H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

Reacting CuI with L in chloroform, we could obtain the metal organic framework (MOF) {[Cu4I4(L)2](H2O)2} n , 3, in a yield of ca. 50%. As the ligand L is highly flexible in the spacer part, strong disorder of the flexible and noncoordinating polyether chains was observed, and we were not able to solve this part of the structure of 3 completely. However, from possible split positions of the polyether moiety, it can be concluded that the structure is unambiguously the MOF described below, with analyses confirming the formation of the MOF.
elements.clean_text:
Having shown that ligand L uses the oxygen donor atoms to coordinate to alkaline earth metal ions, we next tested its coordination behavior toward copper ions.

Coordination of L to Copper Ions: Crystal Structure of {[Cu4I4(L)2](H2O)2} n  (3)

Reacting CuI with L in chloroform, we could obtain the metal organic framework (MOF) {[Cu4I4(L)2](H2O)2} n , 3, in a yield of ca. 50%. As the ligand L is highly flexible in the spacer part, strong disorder of the flexible and noncoordinating polyether chains was observed, and we were not able to solve this part of the structure of 3 completely. However, from possible split positions of the polyether moiety, it can be concluded that the structure is unambiguously the MOF described below, with analyses confirming the formation of the MOF.

elements.content: Compound 3 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric, monoclinic space group I2/a. The asymmetric unit of 3 consists of a Cu4I4 cluster to which four different halves of ligand molecules L are coordinated, binding to the copper ions via the nitrogen atom, respectively. For some of the ligands, the carbon atoms attached to the nicotinic acid groups can be found and attributed in the solid-state structure, but the further polyether chains are strongly disordered. The core of the structure is shown in Figure . The Cu−Cu distances are between 2.64(6)- and 2.66(8)-Å-long. In the literature, many Cu4I4 clusters could be found, with Cu−Cu distances of 2.56−2.75 Å, showing therefore that 3 fits well into this class of compounds. Since the polyether chains were strongly disordered, the question arose of whether 3 is a molecular compound in which two nicotinic moieties of the same cluster unit are connected with each other, yielding a molecular cluster with two ligands in “U” shape, or whether a polymeric network is formed, in which the ligands all connect to neighbor clusters in a stretched conformation (Figure ). To find this out, we tried to describe the structure with split positions for the atoms along the polyether chains. With this treatment, we could clearly see that the cluster units are linked to one another forming a three-dimensional, tetrahedral porous network. In the split positions, additional H-bonded water molecules seem to complicate the pattern. The findings were therefore confirmed by other analytical methods. Thus, thermogravimetric analysis under nitrogen shows a first small mass loss at 160 °C (−2.1%), very likely due to a loss of intercalated solvent, best fitting to two water molecules (calculated 1.99%). A further decomposition at 292 °C indicates the decomposition of organic material (43% measured versus 49% expectedthis is likely due to partial decomposition and carbonate formation). The last peak (−33.3%) at 590 °C corresponds best to the loss of the four iodide atoms of the Cu4I4 units (calculated 32%), leading to remaining copper oxide and carbonate, as indicated by the IR spectrum of the residue.

elements.content: The yellow compound 3 shows a strong green fluorescence under UV light and was therefore investigated for luminescence properties. UV−vis spectroscopy shows an absorption maximum of 3 at 265 nm and, when excited at this wavelength, a strong emission band at 537 nm. This luminescence property of multinuclear copper clusters, especially Cu4I4 units, is known and has been studied in the literature. As the same reaction for obtaining 3 was repeated in an apolar solvent (heptane, hexane), a slightly yellow amorphous precipitate, 3′, formed immediately. Under UV light, the precipitate shows an orange fluorescence, induced probably by slight structural changes, possibly due to different or no intercalated solvent molecules in 3′ compared to 3. When excited at a wavelength of 366 nm, the solid sample in heptanes shows an emission band at 598 nm. TGA analysis of the freshly prepared compound 3′ did not show a small weight loss at 160° as it did for 3, but it has otherwise the same shape and decomposition behavior. After evaporation of the solvent and exposition of 3′ to the air, the green fluorescence of 3 recovers. TGA analysis of this rehydrated sample shows again a small solvent loss around 160° as in 3, indicating a solvatochromism and supporting the idea that water might be the solvent included in the cavities of 3.

UV-vis spectroscopy shows an absorption maximum of 3 at 265 nm and, when excited at this wavelength, a strong emission band at 537 nm. This luminescence property of multinuclear copper clusters, especially Cu4I4 units, is known and has been studied in the literature. As the same reaction for obtaining 3 was repeated in an apolar solvent (heptane, hexane), a slightly yellow amorphous precipitate, 3', formed immediately. Under UV light, the precipitate shows an orange fluorescence, induced probably by slight structural changes, possibly due to different or no intercalated solvent molecules in 3' compared to 3. When excited at a wavelength of 366 nm, the solid sample in heptanes shows an emission band at 598 nm. TGA analysis of the freshly prepared compound 3' did not show a small weight loss at 160° as it did for 3, but it has otherwise the same shape and decomposition behavior. After evaporation of the solvent and exposition of 3' to the air, the green fluorescence of 3 recovers. TGA analysis of this rehydrated sample shows again a small solvent loss around 160° as in 3, indicating a solvatochromism and supporting the idea that water might be the solvent included in the cavities of 3.

elements.content: In order to further confirm our theory that 3 is a MOF, a powder sample has been used to determine the porosity via N2 absorption experiments. Compound 3 turns out to possess a Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) surface of 3.2 m2/g as well as an average pore diameter of 267.8 Å. This indicates a good porosity for such a material. In comparison with other MOFs for hydrogen or carbon dioxide storage, however, compound 3 has a small surface area (3.2 m2/g vs 181−4500 m2/g) but a big pore diameter (267.8 vs 3.6−17 Å), the latter of which is probably responsible for the fast N2 uptake and release. Indeed, it is possible to observe a hysteresis in the N2 isotherms, showing that the pores can be filled and emptied many times without losing this absorption and desorption potential (see the ). The crystal structure, admitting stretched out ligands between the cluster units, confirms the huge dimension of these pores in 3.

elements.content: The experiment with CuI has shown that, if a metal cation only interacts with the nitrogen atoms of L, the ligand does remain in a rather stretched out conformation, similar to the one found in the solid-state structure of L alone. These first three structures, 1−3, confirm that ligand L binds well to Cu(I) ions with the nitrogen donors only, and to the alkaline earth metal ions via the oxygen atoms, so we attempted next to synthesize a mixed-metal compound containing both metal ion types. Crystallographic data for L, 1, 2, and 3 as well as for compounds 4 and 5 are collected in Table .

Upon the slow addition of solid CuI (powder) into a mixture of CaI2 and L in chloroform, the mixed metal, one-dimensional polymeric compound [CaCu3(L)I5(H2O)2] n , 4, was obtained. Its synthesis takes place in a two-step, one-pot reaction: First, the ligand L is allowed to react with the calcium salt for 12 h, and only then is the copper salt added. If the reaction is carried out in the inverse order, compound 3 is obtained as the main product. Compound 4 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pnma. A monomeric unit of 4 consists of a (CaL) complex similar to that in 2, but with two water molecules and one iodide anion connected to the cation instead of three water molecules in 2. Furthermore, the nitrogen atoms of this complex coordinate now to two copper cations, Cu1 and its symmetry equivalent Cu1′. Together with Cu2, these three copper ions form a triangular cluster unit which is μ3-capped on one face by I1. Each of the three edges of the Cu triangle is bridged by one iodide each (I2, I2′, and I3), pointing down the opposite face relative to I1. While I2 and I2′ adopt a simple bridging mode between pairs of copper ions (Cu1−Cu2 and Cu1′−Cu2), I3, which is bridging Cu1−Cu1′, acts as connecting unit to Cu2 of the neighbor cluster unit. Each Cu1 (Cu1′) is tetrahedrally coordinated by one nitrogen atom N1 (N1′) and three iodide anions, I1, I2, and I3 (I1, I2′, I3), while Cu2 is coordinated by four iodide ions, I1, I2, I2′, and I3′. Several CuI clusters and oligomers are known, but the arrangement in 4 is a unique one-dimensional chain motif, based mainly on copper and iodide ions, and to which, in a syndiotactic fashion, the calcium complexes are connected (Figure ).
elements.clean_text:
Coordination of L to Calcium and Copper Ions: Crystal Structure of [CaCu3(L)I5(H2O)2] n , 4 

Upon the slow addition of solid CuI (powder) into a mixture of CaI2 and L in chloroform, the mixed metal, one-dimensional polymeric compound [CaCu3(L)I5(H2O)2] n , 4, was obtained. Its synthesis takes place in a two-step, one-pot reaction: First, the ligand L is allowed to react with the calcium salt for 12 h, and only then is the copper salt added. If the reaction is carried out in the inverse order, compound 3 is obtained as the main product. Compound 4 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pnma. A monomeric unit of 4 consists of a (CaL) complex similar to that in 2, but with two water molecules and one iodide anion connected to the cation instead of three water molecules in 2. Furthermore, the nitrogen atoms of this complex coordinate now to two copper cations, Cu1 and its symmetry equivalent Cu1'. Together with Cu2, these three copper ions form a triangular cluster unit which is μ3-capped on one face by I1. Each of the three edges of the Cu triangle is bridged by one iodide each (I2, I2', and I3), pointing down the opposite face relative to I1. While I2 and I2' adopt a simple bridging mode between pairs of copper ions (Cu1-Cu2 and Cu1'-Cu2), I3, which is bridging Cu1-Cu1', acts as connecting unit to Cu2 of the neighbor cluster unit. Each Cu1 (Cu1') is tetrahedrally coordinated by one nitrogen atom N1 (N1') and three iodide anions, I1, I2, and I3 (I1, I2', I3), while Cu2 is coordinated by four iodide ions, I1, I2, I2', and I3'. Several CuI clusters and oligomers are known, but the arrangement in 4 is a unique one-dimensional chain motif, based mainly on copper and iodide ions, and to which, in a syndiotactic fashion, the calcium complexes are connected (Figure ).

elements.content: The ligand thus adopts a loop shape and uses its oxygen atoms O1, O3, O4, O3′, and O1′ to bind to the calcium cation, leading to the symmetric binding mode as observed in 2. This latter seems to be favored here due to coordination of the N atoms to the copper ions. In contrast to 2, the calcium cation completes its coordination number of eight with two water molecules O5 and O6 and one iodide I4. Similar to 1, H bonding between O5 and I2 of a neighbor unit at a distance of 2.34 Å is observed. The pyridine rings are coplanar due to symmetry. The bond lengths Ca−O in 4 are longer on average than the ones in 2, which is very likely induced by the binding of an anion in the form of I4. For bond valence sum calculation, a value of 2.07 is obtained, which is very close to the formal expected oxidation state of +2 of the Ca2+ ion. A crystallographic mirror plane passes through the calcium ion Ca1 (x, 0.25, y; (e)), as well as the coordinated water molecules O5 and O6, the calcium-bonded iodide I1, I3, and Cu2 (all x, 0.25, y; (e)).

elements.content: As compared to Scheme , where we expected a 1:1 complex between the metal ions M1 and M2, compound 4 shows a ratio of 1:3 between calcium and copper ions. The distance between the two pyridyl nitrogen atoms in compound 2 is 4.28(2)-Å-long and would thus allow in principle one copper ion to be coordinated. With typical Cu−N distances of around 2 Å, this would however lead to an unsuitable N−Cu−N angle for a tetrahedral coordination sphere. Indeed, the two nitrogen atoms of L in 2 form H bonds to one water ligand coordinated to a second calcium complex with distances N−O of ca. 2.7−2.8 Å and an angle N−O−N of ca. 105°. A shorter distance, for example, 2 Å for a possible Cu−N, would lead to a wider angle. In compound 4, the N−N distance within one ligand is, by 5.52(6) Å, widened compared to 2, allowing the ligand to “comfortably” coordinate two copper ions instead of one metal ion.

elements.content: Attempts at obtaining a mixed-metal barium−copper compound (as a precursor for, for example, YBCO) using L were unsuccessful so far. This might be due to the fact that barium cations require a higher coordination number, and the one ligand molecule of L cannot satisfy this, even in the presence of water molecules. We therefore proposed to use the asymmetric ligand L′ for the coordination of barium cations. Similarly as for compound 4, a heterometallic species is easily obtained, this time in a one-step reaction, as shown in the next paragraph.
elements.clean_text: Attempts at obtaining a mixed-metal barium-copper compound (as a precursor for, for example, YBCO) using L were unsuccessful so far. This might be due to the fact that barium cations require a higher coordination number, and the one ligand molecule of L cannot satisfy this, even in the presence of water molecules. We therefore proposed to use the asymmetric ligand L' for the coordination of barium cations. Similarly as for compound 4, a heterometallic species is easily obtained, this time in a one-step reaction, as shown in the next paragraph.

elements.content: A clear yellow solution forms upon the addition of L′ to a suspension of BaI2 and CuI in CH2Cl2, from which single crystals and a precipitate are obtained after slow evaporation. Crystals as well as the precipitate turn out to consist of the heterometallic barium−copper complex {[Ba2Cu3(L′)4I7]·(CH2Cl2)3} n , 5. In contrast to 4, this barium−copper compound can be obtained in a one-pot reaction. This is possible because the ligand L′ is asymmetric and cannot form a coordination polymer network with CuI as in compound 3. Compound 5 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group I2/a with half a molecule in the asymmetric unit. One molecule consists of two barium cations, three copper cations, four L′ ligands, and five iodide counterions (Figure ). Two iodide anions as well as solvent molecules are not directly connected to the cationic entity. Each barium cation is coordinated by two ligand molecules, which bind to the alkaline earth cation via the 10 oxygen donor atoms and in a head-to-head fashion. The Ba−O bonds are comprised between 2.672(6) and 2.995(2) Å, similar as reported in the literature for barium glycol complexes (between 2.61 Å and 3.25 Å), and lead to a bond valence sum for the alkaline earth metal cation of 2.36 (18% deviation from the assumed valence state).

Coordination of L' to Barium and Copper Ions: Crystal Structure of {[Ba2Cu3(L')4I7]⋅(CH2Cl2)3} n , 5 

A clear yellow solution forms upon the addition of L' to a suspension of BaI2 and CuI in CH2Cl2, from which single crystals and a precipitate are obtained after slow evaporation. Crystals as well as the precipitate turn out to consist of the heterometallic barium-copper complex {[Ba2Cu3(L')4I7]⋅(CH2Cl2)3} n , 5. In contrast to 4, this barium-copper compound can be obtained in a one-pot reaction. This is possible because the ligand L' is asymmetric and cannot form a coordination polymer network with CuI as in compound 3. Compound 5 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group I2/a with half a molecule in the asymmetric unit. One molecule consists of two barium cations, three copper cations, four L' ligands, and five iodide counterions (Figure ). Two iodide anions as well as solvent molecules are not directly connected to the cationic entity. Each barium cation is coordinated by two ligand molecules, which bind to the alkaline earth cation via the 10 oxygen donor atoms and in a head-to-head fashion. The Ba-O bonds are comprised between 2.672(6) and 2.995(2) Å, similar as reported in the literature for barium glycol complexes (between 2.61 Å and 3.25 Å), and lead to a bond valence sum for the alkaline earth metal cation of 2.36 (18% deviation from the assumed valence state).

elements.content: One of these two ligands binds to a copper ion Cu1 via the pyridyl moiety. This copper ion (special position 0, y, 0.25 (g)) is connected to a second, symmetry equivalent barium complex, again coordinated by one of the N atoms. Cu1 is furthermore part of a Cu3I5 2− cluster unit, in which three copper ions (Cu1, Cu2, and Cu2′) are bridged by three iodide ions, I2, I2′, and I3, adopting a “twistane” conformation of the six-membered Cu3I3 ring. Cu2 and its symmetry equivalent each carry a terminal iodide ligand, I4, to complete their coordination number to three (angle sum of 355°), while Cu1 has a coordination number of four (tetrahedral). To the best of our knowledge, this type of isolated Cu3I5 2− core is unknown in the literature. Remarkably, within the cationic complex of 5, the correct stoichiometric ratio between the metal ions Ba/Cu = 2:3 is realized, which is needed to produce the superconducting oxide Y1Ba2Cu3O7.

elements.content: One of the two Ba-coordinating ligands does not bind to a second metal ion, and its uncoordinated pyridyl moiety is thus able to form H bonds with one HO group of a neighbor [Ba2(L′)4Cu3I5]2+ unit (Figure ). A ladder-type structure is obtained in which the complexes are arranged in ribbons. The terminal iodide ions of the Cu3I5 unit, I4 and its symmetry equivalent, are H-bonded to one CH2Cl2 molecule each. The lone iodide, I1, and its symmetry equivalent are involved in weak H bonding (C14···I1···O12), connecting the ribbons into a three-dimensional network. The residual CH2Cl2 molecules have only weak interactions to I4, respectively I1, and to carbon atoms of the glycol chain (e.g., Cl6···C21, Cl1···C25, and Cl5···C11).

elements.content: As the goal of the work is to obtain compounds which can be used as precursors, for example, for YBCO or BSCCO, decomposition experiments were carried out in order to check whether compounds 4 and 5 are able to form the parent metal oxide with a composition of 1:3 Ca/Cu and 2:3 Ba/Cu, respectively. For compound 4, the TGA measurement () showed a one-step decomposition process around 290 °C, associated with a strong exothermic peak corresponding to the combustion of the organic material. The total weight loss was 84.4%, which corresponds quite well to the mass of the organic material and the five iodide atoms (82.4%). A sample of 4 was then heated in the air to >290 °C until decomposition, and the obtained black powder was analyzed by IR and XRD. In the FT-IR data of the black powder, some very weak bands around 1600 cm−1 could be observed, showing the presence of remaining organic material, for example, carbonate. Elemental analysis of the metal ion contents reveals an approximate stoichiometry of 1:2.8. The powder was polycrystalline and could be analyzed using XRD (Figure ), showing two phases.
elements.clean_text:
Decomposition Experiments

As the goal of the work is to obtain compounds which can be used as precursors, for example, for YBCO or BSCCO, decomposition experiments were carried out in order to check whether compounds 4 and 5 are able to form the parent metal oxide with a composition of 1:3 Ca/Cu and 2:3 Ba/Cu, respectively. For compound 4, the TGA measurement () showed a one-step decomposition process around 290 °C, associated with a strong exothermic peak corresponding to the combustion of the organic material. The total weight loss was 84.4%, which corresponds quite well to the mass of the organic material and the five iodide atoms (82.4%). A sample of 4 was then heated in the air to >290 °C until decomposition, and the obtained black powder was analyzed by IR and XRD. In the FT-IR data of the black powder, some very weak bands around 1600 cm-1 could be observed, showing the presence of remaining organic material, for example, carbonate. Elemental analysis of the metal ion contents reveals an approximate stoichiometry of 1:2.8. The powder was polycrystalline and could be analyzed using XRD (Figure ), showing two phases.

elements.content: Powder X-ray pattern of a sample of 4 heated in the air over a Bunsen flame. Phase I (red) corresponds to the mixed metal oxide, while phase II (blue) is CuO.

elements.content: The two metal oxides were identified as CuO and the mixed-metal oxide Ca0.828CuO2, the latter being discussed as a residual oxide in the synthesis of superconductors. Furthermore, this compound presents a metastable oxide in the Ca−Cu−O phase diagram. In comparison, compound 1 decomposes only to yield CaCO3 up to 700 °C, above which both carbonate and CaO are formed.

elements.content: Compound 5 decomposes also upon heating to yield a mixture of metal oxides, namely, CuO and Ba88Cu97O220 (see the ). The latter belongs to the group of BaCuO2+x oxides which are studied in the context of their magnetic properties. Among other barium copper oxides, Hodorowicz et al. found BaCuO2 in the Y2O3−BaCO3−CuO system, and Zhang et al. reported that BaCuO2 and Ba2CuO3 can be made in the CuO−BaO system under a partial pressure of 0.21 atm of O2. Ba2Cu3O5, the expected oxide from compound 5, has been obtained by solid-phase reaction, but single-crystal material could not be obtained.

elements.content: Thus, with our method, it is possible to obtain such (i) metastable phases and (ii) possibly also new oxide phases which are difficult to isolate otherwise. In the powder diffraction pattern, all of the peaks can be assigned to these two oxides, which is an important result, as we can thus exclude the formation of carbonates upon combustion in the air. This proves that our approach can indeed lead to interesting oxide materials in the field of superconductors.

elements.content: In this paper, it was shown how a multitopic ligand L was designed and used for the site-selective binding of an alkaline earth and a transition metal ion. It was proven that this selectivity exists when each type of metal ion is reacted alone with the ligand. Upon coordination of L to copper ions, the ligand uses only its N donors to build a porous MOF, 3, which reversibly takes up and releases gas molecules such as nitrogen. As in its free form, the ligand adopts a stretched out conformation. In the case of the calcium complex, two forms of coordination by the ligand are observed, 1 and 2, both of which occur solely via the oxygen atoms of L, which is found in an all-gauche conformation. In case of stepwise addition of the calcium salt to the ligand, followed by the copper salt, one specific ligand conformation is then clearly preferred, yielding finally the mixed-metal compound 4, which can be used as a precursor for metastable mixed oxides. Compound 5 confirms the use of such a ligand type for selectively binding different metal ions and forming heterometallic compounds. As fascinating “side effects”, we were also able to identify new Cu x I y n− units or polymer chains, which were previously unknown.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this paper, it was shown how a multitopic ligand L was designed and used for the site-selective binding of an alkaline earth and a transition metal ion. It was proven that this selectivity exists when each type of metal ion is reacted alone with the ligand. Upon coordination of L to copper ions, the ligand uses only its N donors to build a porous MOF, 3, which reversibly takes up and releases gas molecules such as nitrogen. As in its free form, the ligand adopts a stretched out conformation. In the case of the calcium complex, two forms of coordination by the ligand are observed, 1 and 2, both of which occur solely via the oxygen atoms of L, which is found in an all-gauche conformation. In case of stepwise addition of the calcium salt to the ligand, followed by the copper salt, one specific ligand conformation is then clearly preferred, yielding finally the mixed-metal compound 4, which can be used as a precursor for metastable mixed oxides. Compound 5 confirms the use of such a ligand type for selectively binding different metal ions and forming heterometallic compounds. As fascinating "side effects", we were also able to identify new Cu x I y   n- units or polymer chains, which were previously unknown.

elements.content: It was shown that the heterometallic precursors 4 and 5 yielded oxides, while the homometallic precursor 1 forms carbonate. Even if the oxides formed upon decomposition of 4 and 5 are mixed oxides, this ligand class will allow a rational strategy to synthesize stoichiometrically exact mixed-metal compounds and the mixed-metal oxides via a facile synthetic route, without using air-sensitive materials or processes. Other combinations of metal ions with L and its derivatives such as L′, as well as ligands allowing the selective binding of more than two metal ions, and their decomposition into oxides, are currently under investigation in our laboratory.

Even if the oxides formed upon decomposition of 4 and 5 are mixed oxides, this ligand class will allow a rational strategy to synthesize stoichiometrically exact mixed-metal compounds and the mixed-metal oxides via a facile synthetic route, without using air-sensitive materials or processes. Other combinations of metal ions with L and its derivatives such as L', as well as ligands allowing the selective binding of more than two metal ions, and their decomposition into oxides, are currently under investigation in our laboratory.

elements.content: All reagents were purchased from chemical companies and used without further purification. For single-crystal measurements, a Stoe IPDS II theta, equipped with monochromated Mo Kα radiation (0.71073 Å), was used. Single crystals of L and 1−4 were picked under the microscope, placed in inert oil, and measured at −40 °C. The structures were solved by direct methods (SHELX-97) and refined by full-matrix least-squares procedures on F2 using SHELX-97. Hydrogen atoms were refined where possible, and otherwise added theoretically, using the riding model position parameters. Crystallographic data can be found in the (Table S1), CIF files can be obtained from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, CCDC-702797 (L), CCDC-702796 (1), CCDC-702793 (2), CCDC-702795 (3), CCDC-702794 (4), and CCDC-724089 (5). Copies of these data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk or e-mail, deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk. Powder X-ray spectra were collected on a Nonius Enraf FR 590 X-ray generator with mounted Stoe StadiP using Cu Kalpha1 radiation (1.5406 Å). IR and NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Tensor 27 and on a Bruker AM 360, respectively. UV−vis spectra were collected on a Perkin-Elmer Lambda 25. Fluorescence measurements were performed on a Perkin-Elmer LS 50B. TGA were recorded on a Mettler Toledo TGA7SDTA851. BET measurements were performed on a micrometrics Gemini unit. AAS measurements were done on a Shimadzu AA-6300 machine and elemental analysis performed on a EA110 CE Instruments at the University of Basel, Switzerland.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All reagents were purchased from chemical companies and used without further purification. For single-crystal measurements, a Stoe IPDS II theta, equipped with monochromated Mo Kα radiation (0.71073 Å), was used. Single crystals of L and 1-4 were picked under the microscope, placed in inert oil, and measured at -40 °C. The structures were solved by direct methods (SHELX-97) and refined by full-matrix least-squares procedures on F2 using SHELX-97. Hydrogen atoms were refined where possible, and otherwise added theoretically, using the riding model position parameters. Crystallographic data can be found in the  (Table S1), CIF files can be obtained from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, CCDC-702797 (L), CCDC-702796 (1), CCDC-702793 (2), CCDC-702795 (3), CCDC-702794 (4), and CCDC-724089 (5). Copies of these data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk or e-mail, deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk. Powder X-ray spectra were collected on a Nonius Enraf FR 590 X-ray generator with mounted Stoe StadiP using Cu Kalpha1 radiation (1.5406 Å). IR and NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Tensor 27 and on a Bruker AM 360, respectively. UV-vis spectra were collected on a Perkin-Elmer Lambda 25. Fluorescence measurements were performed on a Perkin-Elmer LS 50B. TGA were recorded on a Mettler Toledo TGA7SDTA851. BET measurements were performed on a micrometrics Gemini unit. AAS measurements were done on a Shimadzu AA-6300 machine and elemental analysis performed on a EA110 CE Instruments at the University of Basel, Switzerland.

Synthesis of L, [C20H24O7N2]

Oxalylchloride (5.1 mL, 0.06 mol, 1.5 equiv) was dropped slowly into a suspension of nicotinic acid (5 g, 0.04 mol, 1 equiv) in dichloromethane (100 mL). The mixture was then stirred overnight at room temperature. The solution was filtered, and the solid was dried under reduced pressure.

elements.content: The so-obtained white nicotinic acid chloride (5.76 g, 0.04 mol, 1 equiv) was suspended in toluene (100 mL), and triethylamine (8.6 mL, 0.06 mol, 1.5 equiv) was slowly added. The reaction mixture was refluxed for 10 min and allowed to cool down. A solution of tetraethylene glycol (3.4 mL, 0.02 mol, 0.5 equiv) in toluene was added slowly and the whole mixture was again refluxed for 8 h at 130 °C. The brown liquid was stirred overnight at room temperature. Then, dichloromethane (80 mL) was added, and this phase was extracted twice with water (200 mL). The organic phase was dried over MgSO4 and filtered, and the solvent was removed under reduced pressure to yield a microcrystalline powder of L. X-ray-suitable single crystals can be grown by dissolving L in dichloromethane, which is allowed to evaporate at room temperature (yield 80%).

Ligand L (0.4 g, 1 mmol, 1 equiv) and CaI2 (0.32 g, 1 mmol, 1 equiv) are dissolved together in chloroform (20 mL). The solution is stirred overnight at room temperature. The yellow reaction mixture is then filtered, and the filtrate is allowed to evaporate slowly at room temperature. After one week, yellow crystals of 1 grow (yield 60%).

For scaleup, L (2 g, 5 mmol, 1 equiv) and CaI2 (1.15 g, 5.2 mmol, 1.2 equiv) are dissolved together in a minimum amount of chloroform (around 60 mL). The solution is stirred overnight at room temperature. The precipitation is forced by adding hexane; then, the solution is filtered and washed with chloroform and acetone. The bulk material is characterized by powder diffraction.

Since in solution both compounds 1 and 2 are equal, the analyses in solution were drawn together.

Synthesis of 2, [Ca(L)(H2O)3)]I2⋅(CHCl3)2 

Ligand L (0.4 g, 1 mmol, 1 equiv) and CaI2 (0.32 g, 1 mmol, 1 equiv) are dissolved in chloroform (20 mL). The solution is stirred overnight at room temperature. The yellow reaction mixture is then filtered, and the filtrate is allowed to stand in the refrigerator at -24 °C. After a few days, nice pale yellow temperature-sensitive crystals grow (yield 40%).

Synthesis of 3, {[Cu4I4(L)2](H2O)2} n  

CuI (0.25 g, 2 mmol, 2 equiv) is suspended in chloroform (20 mL). After the addition of L (0.4 g, 1 mmol, 1 equiv), the gray suspension clarifies in a few minutes to a yellow solution. The mixture is stirred overnight and is layered with hexane. After a few days, big rhombic crystals grow from the solution (yield 80%).

Synthesis of 4, [CaCu3(L)I5(H2O)2]

Ligand L (0.2 g, 0.5 mmol, 1 equiv) and CaI2 (0.14 g, 0.5 mmol, 1 equiv) are dissolved in dichloromethane (10 mL) and acetonitrile (10 mL) and stirred for a few hours. In small portions, CuI (0.24 g, 0.5 mmol, 3 equiv) is added, and the mixture is stirred overnight. The solution is filtered and allowed to evaporate slowly. After a few weeks, nice yellow crystals grow (50%).

For the bulk synthesis and scaleup, L (2 g, 5.0 mmol, 1 equiv) and CaI2 (1.4 g, 5 mmol, 1 equiv) are dissolved in a minimum of absolute dichloromethane (ca. 60 mL) and stirred for 12 h. CuI (2.82 g, 10 mmol, 3 equiv) is dissolved in a mixture of 1:1 dichloromethane/acetonitrile and added. The solution is stirred overnight, and a precipitate forms. To the reaction mixture, diethyl ether and n-hexanes are added to complete the precipitation. The powder is filtered and washed several times with ethanol to dissolve unreacted starting material; then, it is dried in a vacuum. The bulk material is characterized by powder diffraction and confirmed to be compound 4.

Synthesis of 5, {[Ba2Cu3(L')4I7](CH2Cl2)3} n  

CuI (0.6 g, 0.5 mmol, 3 equiv) and BaI2 (0.4 g, 0.25 mmol, 1 equiv) are dissolved in absolute dichloromethane or chloroform (30 mL). Ligand L' (0.6 g, 0.5 mmol, 2 equiv) in a minimum of solvent is dropped into the solution, and the mixture is stirred overnight. A majority of 5 precipitates, is filtered off, and is washed with dichloromethane. The mother liquor is layered with n-hexanes and cooled to 4 °C to obtain crystals (yield 55%).

cln_elements.content: In order to further confirm our theory that 3 is a MOF, a powder sample has been used to determine the porosity via N2 absorption experiments. Compound 3 turns out to possess a Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) surface of 3.2 m2/g as well as an average pore diameter of 267.8 Å. This indicates a good porosity for such a material. In comparison with other MOFs for hydrogen or carbon dioxide storage, however, compound 3 has a small surface area (3.2 m2/g vs 181−4500 m2/g) but a big pore diameter (267.8 vs 3.6−17 Å), the latter of which is probably responsible for the fast N2 uptake and release. Indeed, it is possible to observe a hysteresis in the N2 isotherms, showing that the pores can be filled and emptied many times without losing this absorption and desorption potential (see the ). The crystal structure, admitting stretched out ligands between the cluster units, confirms the huge dimension of these pores in 3.

In comparison with other MOFs for hydrogen or carbon dioxide storage, however, compound 3 has a small surface area (3.2 m2/g vs 181-4500 m2/g) but a big pore diameter (267.8 vs 3.6-17 Å), the latter of which is probably responsible for the fast N2 uptake and release. Indeed, it is possible to observe a hysteresis in the N2 isotherms, showing that the pores can be filled and emptied many times without losing this absorption and desorption potential (see the ). The crystal structure, admitting stretched out ligands between the cluster units, confirms the huge dimension of these pores in 3.
